comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: Seen on static ‘open house’ display with timber access steps for visitors to view cockpit, a supersonic RF-8A Crusader photo reconnaissance jet possibly at its home base of MCAS El Toro California. Vought RF-8A Crusader 146870 of US Marine Corps VMCJ-3 ‘Eyes of the Corp’ with squadron tail code TN. (Marine Composite Reconnaissance Squadron Three – a US Marine Corps combined photo reconnaissance & ECM unit) VMCJ-3 had the RF-8A from 1960 to 1965 and served as the main training unit for annual deployment of relief cadres to active unit VMCJ-1 in the Pacific. It changed to the RF-4B Phantom from 1965. RF-8A Crusader 146870 was returned to LTV in the USA and upgraded to RF-8G during 1965-1966: www.joebaugher.com/navy_fighters/f8_10.html (info courtesy of Professor Joe Baugher, Chicago Illinois) RF-8G 146870 was lost on 3rd August 1966 in circumstances as yet unknown 38 miles from Honolulu VORTAC beacon in Hawaii. Pilot Lieutenant (junior grade) F. D. Litvin ejected and was recovered safely. www.ejection-history.org.uk/Aircraft_by_Type/F_8_Crusader... (info courtesy of www.ejection-history.org.uk) …………………………………………………………………………………………… PLEASE NOTE; Lieutenant (junior grade) F. D. Litvin suffered a second ejection and was again fortunately rescued, this time from RF-8G 146899 when shot down during a mission over North Vietnam on October 8, 1966, while with VFP-63 Detachment A from CVA-43 USS Coral Sea deployed to the Gulf of Tonkin during the Vietnam War. www.flickr.com/photos/sdasmarchives/4559128035/
